title: cata-list
description: Useful lists of some of the best info, media, tools, and quotes for those who seek to understand and improve this world.

articles.title: Clear Link Between AstraZeneca Vaccine and Rare Blood Clots in Brain, EMA Official Tells Paper
articles.description: There is a link between AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine and very rare blood clots in the brain but the possible causes are still unknown, a senior official for the European Medicines Agency (EMA) said in an interview published on Tuesday.

articles.title: On the Miserable Necessity of Doing Censorship Stories in Pairs
articles.description: 'Meet the Censored' will now come out in sets of left and right bans, in the (probably vain) hope that fewer people will cheer news of deletions and suspensions

articles.title: How a Facial Recognition Tool Found Its Way Into Hundreds of US Police Departments, Schools, and Taxpayer-Funded Organizations
articles.description: A BuzzFeed News investigation has found that employees at law enforcement agencies across the US ran thousands of Clearview AI facial recognition searches — often without the knowledge of the public or even their own departments.

articles.title: Navy Still Has No Idea What Mysterious Drones That Stalked Its Ships for Days Were
articles.description: The U.S. Navy still has no idea who sent a swarm of drones to buzz warships off the coast of California in July 2019, or really even what kind of drones they were or what they were doing.

articles.title: Cops Crowdfunded Their K-9's Hospital Bills — Then Quietly Admitted They Had Shot Him
articles.description: The cops in Thurston County, Washington, made no such efforts to support the recovery of the man they shot and who had to be hospitalized.

articles.title: 553,000,000 Reasons Not to Let Facebook Make Decisions About Your Privacy
articles.description: Another day, another horrific Facebook privacy scandal. We know what comes next: Facebook will argue that losing a lot of our data means bad third-party actors are the real problem that we should trust Facebook to make more decisions about our data to protect against them. If history is any...

articles.title: Cells Form Into Living 'Xenobots' on Their Own
articles.description: Embryonic cells can self-assemble into new forms that don't resemble the bodies they usually generate, challenging old ideas of what defines an organism.

articles.title: 533 Million Facebook Users' Phone Numbers and Personal Data Have Been Leaked Online
articles.description: The data includes phone numbers, Facebook IDs, full names, locations, birthdates, bios, and, in some cases, email addresses.

articles.title: Lithium Battery Costs Have Fallen by 98% in Three Decades
articles.description: In a few years electric vehicles may cost the same as their combustion-engine counterparts | Graphic detail

articles.title: Exclusive: Oxford Kept COVID-19 Vaccine Trial Volunteers in Dark About Dosing Error, Letter Shows
articles.description: - About 1,500 of the initial volunteers in a late-stage clinical trial of the Oxford/AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine were given the wrong dose, but weren't informed that a mistake had been made after the blunder was discovered, documents obtained by Reuters show.

articles.title: The US Is Finally Trying to Unlock the Power of Wave Energy
articles.description: After decades of false starts, the federal approval of a new testing site off the coast of Oregon could give the technology a much-needed jolt.

articles.title: Nuclear Should Be Considered Part of Clean Energy Standard, White House Says
articles.description: Biden's plan goes beyond most states' definitions of clean power.

articles.title: Fossil Fuels Companies Got Billions in Bailouts, Then Fired Thousands of Workers
articles.description: Fossil fuel companies made out like bandits from last year's government bailout. Now, new data shows that big names in the industry laid off tens of thousands of workers last year while padding their bank accounts with public money.

articles.title: Is Traditional Liberalism Vanishing?
articles.description: 'Mighty Ira,' a documentary about legendary former ACLU chief Ira Glasser, is simultaneously inspiring and unnerving

articles.title: We Sampled Tap Water Across the US – and Found Arsenic, Lead and Toxic Chemicals
articles.description: A nine-month investigation by the Guardian and Consumer Reports found alarming levels of forever chemicals, arsenic and lead in samples taken across the US

articles.title: Trump's EPA Helped Erase Records of Almost 270,000 Pounds of Carcinogenic Pollution
articles.description: Investigative reporter Sharon Lerner explains how 270,000 pounds of the chemical ethylene oxide vanished from the public record.

articles.title: Data Withheld From WHO Team Probing COVID-19 Origins in China: Tedros
articles.description: (This March 30 story removes reference in 7th para to the European Union which did not sign that joint statement)

articles.title: Big Chunks of Corporate Tax Cuts End Up in Executives' Pockets
articles.description: A new study finds that recent tax breaks may be worth hundreds of billions in personal boodle for corporate royalty.

articles.title: Has American Liberalism Abandoned Free Speech? Interview With Thomas Frank
articles.description: The celebrated author writes an article in The Guardian opposing censorship, and is stunned by negative responses

articles.title: Whistleblower: Ubiquiti Breach 'Catastrophic'
articles.description: On Jan. 11, Ubiquiti Inc. [NYSE:UI] — a major vendor of cloud-enabled Internet of Things (IoT) devices such as routers, network video recorders and security cameras — disclosed that a breach involving a third-party cloud provider had exposed customer account…

articles.title: Jordan Peterson's Fairytale World
articles.description: The psychology professor understands that our cherished beliefs are just stories

articles.title: Boston Dynamics' New Robot Doesn't Dance. It Has a Warehouse Job
articles.description: Called Stretch, the machine may look wildly different than its famous cousins Spot and Atlas, but it shares a ton of their DNA.

articles.title: Gallup: U.S. Church Membership Dips Below 50% for First Time
articles.description: It's the first time the poll indicates a majority of Americans do not belong to a church.

articles.title: Journalists Attack the Powerless, Then Self-Victimize to Bar Criticisms of Themselves
articles.description: Powerful media figures now invoke sexist and racist tropes to cast themselves as so fragile and marginalized that critiques of their work constitute bullying and assault.

articles.title: Master List of Official Russia Claims That Proved to Be Bogus
articles.description: The Director of National Intelligence releases a report, and the press rushes to kick the football again.

articles.title: SolarWinds Hack Reportedly Accessed Emails for Key DHS Officials
articles.description: SolarWinds hackers reportedly compromised the email of Homeland Security officials, including acting Secretary Chad Wolf.

articles.title: How U.S. Media Lost the Trust of the Public
articles.description: A global pandemic, anti-racism protests and a turbulent U.S. presidential election had Americans glued to their screens in 2020, but as people consumed more news, they began to trust media less, surveys suggested. The CBC documentary Big News takes a look at why the public lost faith in the media an…

articles.title: America's Obsession With Wipes Is Tearing Up Sewer Systems
articles.description: Across the U.S., cities and towns are being forced to throw more money at solving blockages as consumers buy (and flush) more wipes than ever.

articles.title: Congress, in a Five-Hour Hearing, Demands Tech CEOs Censor the Internet Even More Aggressively
articles.description: The repressive objective of the Democratic-controlled Congress is to transfer the power to police and censor political discourse from these tech giants to themselves.

articles.title: Alternatives to Censorship: Interview With Matt Stoller
articles.description: As Congress once again demands that Silicon Valley crack down on speech, the Director of Research at the American Economic Liberties Project outlines the real problem, and better solutions

articles.title: NASA's TESS Spacecraft Has Already Found 2,200 Possible Planets
articles.description: NASA's TESS spacecraft has already found 2,200 potential planets, surpassing its original goal and raising hope of finding Earth-like worlds.

articles.title: Scotland's Renewable Energy Matched 97 Percent of Demand in 2020
articles.description: 97.4 percent of Scotland's gross electric consumption came from clean energy sources in 2020.

articles.title: Eating Mostly Restaurant Meals Linked to Higher Risk of Early Death
articles.description: Dining out often might come with a hidden cost down the road, new research suggests. The study found an association between frequently eating at restaurants and a higher risk of dying earlier, along with deaths caused by cardiovascular disease and cancer.

articles.title: The Death of Humor
articles.description: Review of 'Killer Cartoons,' edited by David Wallis, and 'White,' by Bret Easton Ellis

articles.title: The Tyranny of Diversity Training
articles.description: America is exporting its Calvinistic tendencies to British workplaces

articles.title: Taiwan Reports Largest Ever Incursion by Chinese Air Force
articles.description: Twenty Chinese military aircraft entered Taiwan's air defence identification zone on Friday, in the largest incursion yet reported by the island's defence ministry and marking a dramatic escalation of tension across the Taiwan Strait.

articles.title: The US Military Is Poisoning Communities Across the US With Toxic Chemicals
articles.description: The Department of Defense has ordered the burning of 20m pounds of AFFF – despite risks to human health

articles.title: The Dark Web Is Teeming With Vaccine Listings Right Now
articles.description: Vendors are cashing in on people desperate to leapfrog the line—or falsely certify that they got the shot.

articles.title: Researchers Found a Way to Send Tiny Robots Into Mouse Brains
articles.description: In a mind-bending development, a team of researchers in China have managed to treat brain tumors in mice by delivering drugs to the tissues using microscopic robots. The robots jumped from the mice's bloodstreams into their brains by being coated in E. coli, which tricked the rodents' immune systems…

articles.title: Deforestation and Palm Oil Plantations Are Fueling a Disease Boom, Study Suggests
articles.description: New research presents evidence that activities such as deforestation, building palm oil plantations, and even converting grassy areas into new forests are associated with outbreaks of disease, particularly those transmitted by mosquitoes and other vector animals.

articles.title: The U.S. Intelligence Community, Flouting Laws, Is Increasingly Involving Itself in Domestic Politics
articles.description: A letter from House Intelligence Committee members demands answers from the DNI about illegal breaches of the wall guarding against CIA and NSA domestic activity.

articles.title: After Dramatic Rebuke, AstraZeneca Lowers Vaccine Efficacy Estimate—a Little
articles.description: Independent experts called the earlier analysis 'outdated and potentially misleading.'

articles.title: A Biden Appointee's Troubling Views on the First Amendment
articles.description: Columbia law professor Timothy Wu wonders if the First Amendment is 'obsolete,' and believes in 'returning the country to the kind of media environment that prevailed in the 1950s.'

articles.title: Top Saudi Official Issued Death Threat Against UN's Khashoggi Investigator
articles.description: Senior official twice threatened to have Agnès Callamard 'taken care of' in meeting with UN colleagues in Geneva in January 2020

articles.title: AstraZeneca Messes Up Again, Called Out for Using Old Data in U.S. Trial Results
articles.description: Pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca isn't running out of rakes to step on anytime soon. Less than a day after the company announced promising preliminary results from the U.S. trial of its covid-19 vaccine jointly developed with Oxford University, an independent panel of scientists monitoring the stu…

articles.title: NASA's New Mars Rover Is About to Spawn a Tiny Helicopter
articles.description: Ingenuity, a 4-pound helicopter, is almost ready to fly.

articles.title: Ultrasound Reads Monkey Brains, Opening New Way to Control Machines With Thought
articles.description: Imaging with sound could offer a less invasive way to send commands to prostheses

articles.title: Fossil Fuels Would Be Screwed Without U.S. Government Propping Them Up
articles.description: Conservatives have argued against regulating the fossil fuel industry for the climate's sake, claiming that doing so would interfere with the free market. A new study shows that's a fairy tale. The invisible hand isn't at work—implicit government subsidies are.

articles.title: Australia to Rescue Thousands as Sydney Faces Worst Floods in 60 Years
articles.description: Australia was set on Monday to evacuate thousands more people from suburbs in Sydney's west, battered by the worst flooding in 60 years, with torrential rains expected to continue for another day or two.

articles.title: High-Income Tax Avoidance Far Larger Than Thought, New Paper Estimates
articles.description: The very top sliver of high-income Americans may underreport their income at levels far beyond what was suggested by prior IRS research, according to a new paper.

articles.title: Philippines Says 220 Chinese Militia Vessels Seen in Disputed Waters This Month
articles.description: The Philippines expressed concern about hundreds of Chinese military vessels it said were spotted this month in the disputed South China Sea, the latest example of tension in the crucial waterway.

articles.title: Police Warn Students to Avoid Science Website
articles.description: Universities are urged to block a science research website, which police say could put data at risk.

articles.title: Trump EPA Invited Companies to Revise Pollution Records of a Potent Carcinogen
articles.description: After ethylene oxide was shown to be 30 times more carcinogenic than previously thought, polluters began rewriting their toxic history — with the EPA's help.

articles.title: Oil Firms Knew Decades Ago Fossil Fuels Posed Grave Health Risks, Files Reveal
articles.description: Exclusive: documents seen by Guardian show companies fought clean-air rules despite being aware of harm caused by air pollution

articles.title: Satellites Can Help Detect When a Volcano's About to Blow
articles.description: Researchers used thermal radiation data to find patterns in recent eruptions—providing another metric to help get ahead of a potentially deadly blast.

articles.title: Drugmakers Promise Investors They'll Soon Hike Covid-19 Vaccine Prices
articles.description: Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson pledged affordable vaccines — but only as long as there's a 'pandemic.'

articles.title: Plastic Particles Pass From Mothers Into Foetuses, Rat Study Shows
articles.description: Nanoparticles found in foetal brains and hearts, but impact on human health is as yet unknown

articles.title: The Campaign of Lies Against Journalist Jesse Singal — and Why It Matters
articles.description: One of the odd-seeming aspects of progressive cancel culture is that many of the figures targeted by mobs aren't especially conservative in their views. Rather, the victims tend to be heterodox lib…

articles.title: One Company Wants to Sell the Feds Location Data From Every Car on Earth
articles.description: Federal agencies already buy tons of user data; one vendor is now being sued.

articles.title: Putin Offers Biden Public Talks After U.S. President Says He Thinks He Is a Killer
articles.description: President Vladimir Putin said on Thursday that he and U.S. President Joe Biden should hold live online talks in coming days after Biden said he thought the Russian leader was a killer and diplomatic ties sank to a new post-Cold War low.

articles.title: Aaugh! a Brief List of Official Russia Claims That Proved to Be Bogus
articles.description: The Director of National Intelligence releases a report, and the press rushes to kick the football again.

articles.title: Scientists Grow Mouse Embryos in a Mechanical Womb
articles.description: Biologists have long held that a fetus needs a living uterus to develop. Maybe not anymore.

articles.title: This Surveillance Company Claims It Can Track Nearly Any Car in Real-Time
articles.description: A document obtained by the office of Sen. Ron Wyden shows Ulysses claims to be able to 'remotely geolocate' cars in 'nearly any country,' with the exceptions of Cuba and North Korea.

articles.title: Texas Utility Chair Resigns After Leaked Call Pledging to Help Banks
articles.description: The last standing member of Texas's Public Utility Commission handed in his resignation on Tuesday following a report that he assured out-of-state investors who made big profits from last month's blackouts that he was working to help them keep their money.

articles.title: Journalists, Illustrating How They Operate, Yesterday Spread a Significant Lie All Over Twitter
articles.description: Eager to obtain vindication for the pre-election falsehood they spread about the Hunter Biden story, journalists falsely claim that the CIA blamed Russia for it.

articles.title: Britain's Academic Free Speech Bill
articles.description: The British Education Secretary, Gavin Williamson, recently set out proposals to strengthen free speech and academic freedom at universities in England. These include: appointing an Academic Freedo…

articles.title: With Ratings Down, the Networks Hunt for a Trump Replacement
articles.description: Trump saved the cable news business once. Without him, things are looking bleak again. Who will news outlets find to feed the outrage machine?

articles.title: How Do Big Media Outlets So Often 'Independently Confirm' Each Other's Falsehoods?
articles.description: The Washington Post's media-spread error about Trump's Georgia call shows the deceitful playbook first invented to undermine Trump and promote Russiagate.

articles.title: Science Goes Rogue
articles.description: Social justice activists have been arguing for some time that scientific societies and institutions need to address systemic sexism and racism in STEM disciplines. However, their rationale is often…

articles.title: The UK Is Secretly Testing a Controversial Web Snooping Tool
articles.description: The country passed its Investigatory Powers Act in 2016. Now, its building what could be the most powerful data collection system used by any democratic nation.

articles.title: Is Consciousness Everywhere?
articles.description: Experience is in unexpected places, including in all animals, large and small, and perhaps even in brute matter itself.

articles.title: Google Must Face $5B Lawsuit Over Tracking Private Internet Use, Judge Rules
articles.description: Judge finds tech giant didn't notify users their data could still be collected in incognito mode.

articles.title: Congressional Testimony: The Leading Activists for Online Censorship Are Corporate Journalists
articles.description: A hearing of the House Subcommittee focused on anti-trust and monopoly abuses examines the role of the corporate media in these growing pathologies.

articles.title: Indoor-Grown Weed Is Spewing Carbon Into the Atmosphere
articles.description: Most legal marijuana is grown in a controlled environment. A study just quantified how much damage that's doing to the planet.

articles.title: California Will Soon Be Home to the World's First 3D-Printed Housing Community and It's Powered by Solar and a Tesla Powerwall
articles.description: Mighty Buildings will use 3D printers and robots to build the $15 million community of homes in California's Coachella Valley.

articles.title: The Sovietization of the American Press
articles.description: The transformation from phony 'objectivity' to open one-party orthodoxy hasn't been an improvement

articles.title: New SWAT Drone Smashes Windows, Opens Doors, and Negotiates With Suspects
articles.description: A new UAV marketed to police SWAT teams inlcudes a feature we've never seen before: The drone has a whirling blade that smashes glass.

articles.title: Journalists Start Demanding Substack Censor Its Writers: To Bar Critiques of Journalists
articles.description: This new political battle does not break down along left v. right lines. This is an information war waged by corporate media to silence any competition or dissent.

articles.title: Criticizing Public Figures, Including Influential Journalists, Is Not Harassment or Abuse
articles.description: As social media empowers uncredentialed people to be heard, society's most powerful actors seek to cast themselves as victims and delegitimize all critiques.

articles.title: Why We Need a 'Moon Ark' to Store Frozen Seeds, Sperm and Eggs From 6.7 Million Earth Species
articles.description: An ambitious project has been unveiled to construct a solar-powered lunar ark in the Moon's underground lava tubes. The plan is to preserve human, animal, plant fungi samples in the event of a global crisis.

articles.title: Russia Turns Away From NASA, Says It Will Work With China on a Moon Base
articles.description: China wants a long-term presence on the Moon in the 2030s.

articles.title: SpaceX Moves to Beam Starlink Internet Into Trucks, Boats, and Aircraft
articles.description: Pending FCC approval, SpaceX's Starlink internet is expanding beyond homes for the road, sea, and air.

articles.title: Programmable Optical Quantum Computer Arrives Late, Steals the Show
articles.description: New optical quantum computer overcomes previous limits, looks like a winner.

articles.title: Chinese Hackers Targeted SolarWinds Customers in Parallel With Russian Op
articles.description: New data suggests that Russia wasn't the only nation-state hacking customers.

articles.title: Austria Suspends AstraZeneca COVID-19 Vaccine Batch After Death
articles.description: Austrian authorities have suspended inoculations with a batch of AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine as a precaution while investigating the death of one person and the illness of another after the shots, a health agency said on Sunday.

articles.title: In Defense of Substack
articles.description: UCLA professor Sarah T. Roberts mourns the good old days of gatekeeping and credential-worship

articles.title: Trust in Media Hits New Crisis Low
articles.description: Fewer than half of all Americans trust traditional media.

articles.title: American Chipmakers Had a Toxic Problem. Then They Outsourced It
articles.description: Twenty-five years ago, U.S. tech companies pledged to stop using chemicals that caused miscarriages and birth defects. They failed to ensure that their Asian suppliers did the same.

articles.title: Meet the (Unsuccessfully) Censored: Jesse Singal and Katie Herzog
articles.description: The media business keeps trying to ruin Jesse Singal and Katie Herzog, and they keep prospering. On the loony Substack controversy, and the paradox of moral panic in media

articles.title: Daniel Ellsberg Talks About Whistleblowing, the Pervasiveness of Official Lies, and the Dangers of the Espionage Act
articles.description: In an interview with 'Useful Idiots,' Daniel Ellsberg talks about official deceptions, and how he was upheld as the 'good' whistleblower to disparage the likes of Ed Snowden and Julian Assange

articles.title: The Accellion Breach Keeps Getting Worse — and More Expensive
articles.description: What started as a few vulnerabilities in firewall equipment has snowballed into a global extortion spree.

articles.title: For Our Own Good, We All Need a Glimpse of the Evil Queen
articles.description: I had a client many years ago who was a real-life version of Sleeping Beauty. She was tall, blonde-haired, razor thin (as the saying goes), and profoundly unhappy. She was enrolled in a local junio…

articles.title: Chinese, Russian Hackers Reportedly Stole European Vaccine Data
articles.description: Both China and Russia were reportedly behind two cyberattacks last year at the European Medicines Agency that compromised documents related to covid-19 vaccines and treatments.

articles.title: How to Tell Which Emails Quietly Track You
articles.description: Your emails know more about you than you might think, like when you open them or when you forward them to others. But you can reclaim your privacy.

articles.title: This Rapid 3D-Printing Method Could Be the Secret to Developing 3D-Printed Organs
articles.description: We may not have flying cars yet, but 3D-printed organs? That sci-fi fantasy just got one step closer to reality thanks to a rapid 3D-printing method developed by University of Buffalo engineers.

articles.title: A North Carolina Pipeline Caused the Biggest Gas Spill in Decades
articles.description: A slowly-unfolding, little-reported-on saga in North Carolina involves a company controlled by the Koch brothers and Shell, and a pipeline that has been transporting dirty energy for decades. And it has implications for pipelines everywhere across the U.S.

articles.title: China's and Russia's Spying Sprees Will Take Years to Unpack
articles.description: Full extent of SolarWinds hack, Hafnium's attack on Exchange Server may never be known.

articles.title: World Wastes 1 Billion Tons of Food a Year, and It's Frying the Planet
articles.description: If you've ever overstuffed your fridge and let some leftovers go bad in the back of it, you're not alone. People toss more than 1 billion tons of food in the trash every year, according to a new United Nations report. But it doesn't have to be this way.

articles.title: Under Intense Pressure, WHO Skips Summary Report on Coronavirus Origin
articles.description: The full report, however, is expected the week of March 15.

articles.title: Chinese Hacking Spree Hit an 'Astronomical' Number of Victims
articles.description: A single group appears to have infiltrated tens of thousands of Microsoft Exchange servers in an ongoing onslaught.
